challenges.title: Introduction
challenges.testCode: // test('message', () => expect(...))
challenges.supplementaryContent:
Welcome to module 1! Where we'll be using HTML, CSS and JavaScript to dive into the basics of programming.

# What you will learn

* Foundational programming skills like
  * Variables
  * Functions
  * How computers represent information and what _types_ of information you can represent
  * Data structure
  * Algorithms
* How to build your own website
* How to put a website online

The challenges in this module will move fast and include a lot of video content. These are your first steps into the world of programming, and if you continue along this path you'll look back some day and remember where it all started: Right here!

Onward.

challenges.title: HTML, the language of the web
challenges.supplementaryContent:
HTML is the reason there is anything online to look at. It's ubiquitous online because without it there would be nothing. When you visit Facebook or Google or Reddit you're reading HTML. You're reading HTML right now. # What is HTML? HTML is a language for putting content into web browsers and telling browsers what content means what. Consider the following items: * Some plain text * Some **_bold italic_** text * Some `code` text It's easy to tell the difference and that's the point. Different parts of a webpage mean different things, and as programmers we need a way of telling a web browser what's what. Let's take another example. Consider the list above. Howe does the browser know that its' a list? How does it know to include a small dot in front of the text? The answer is HTML. Consider what that three-item list looks like to you, the reader, and also consider what it looks like in code: ```html
  • Some plain text
  • Some bold italic text
  • Some code text
``` It looks quite different! The code above is what the browser sees. A `ul` with some `li`s inside tell the browser we want a list. Putting some text inside a `strong` and an `em` will make the text **bold** and _italic_ respectively. # Why are we learning HTML? A few reasons: ## 1. It's visual What you write in code will appear on screen. This is hugely important when you're first learning. Programmers specialize in telling computers what to do, and computers don't always give you visual feedback to let you know that your commands are achieving the desired result. Think about the clock on your phone. Seem simple right? It shows the time. It also adjusts for daylight savings time, or if you physically enter a different timezone. It can display the time in 24-hour format or AM-PM format. Consider this: * How does your phone know the time? * How does the clock update when daylight savings time shifts or when you step off of a plan? This functionality, which we all take for granted, was programmed by someone. Imagine you are that person. If you program the phone to update its time based on your GPS location, how do you know it worked? There's no immediate visual feedback to tell you whether your code worked or not. If you're writing HTML there is visual feedback, so you will know immediately if your code is doing what you want it to. ## 2. It gives you real skills, quickly If you learn the basics of HTML, guess what? You can make your own website. In fact, in this course we'll walk you through creating a website from scratch and getting it online for free. At the end of this module you will be able to build something real, that you can see online and show to other people. In fact, using just the skills in this first module you can even build websites for other people and **get paid to do it**. There are many people around the world who make a living this way. Of course our goal is to give you the skills to be a full software engineer so we will go well beyond HTML. Which brings us to the final point... ## 3. It's foundational HTML is everywhere, and not just on the web. Consider Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, Google, Amazon, Netflix, etc. These massive companies all rely on HTML. They all have mobile apps too, but the web component is a significant part of their business. Consider also that the principles you learn while building HTML can translate into mobile app development as well. We will touch on this significantly in later parts of the course. For now, let's focus on HTML and dive in. # Tags All those things you saw in the code at the beginning of the lesson, `
    `, `
  • `, ``, etc. are called tags. Don't worry, you don't have to remember this yet, but you will over time because this is how programmers talk about HTML and how we walk about it in our videos. ## Anatomy of an HTML tag Tags usually have two parts: * The opening tag * The closing tag Opening tags include a `<` symbol, followed by the name of the tag, followed by the `>` symbol. Closing tags are almost exactly the same. The only difference is that closing tags have a `/` symbol right after the `<`. Example: * `

    I'm a paragraph

    ` Reading through one character at a time, the opening "P tag" is `<` + `p` + `>`. The closing P tag is `<` + `/` + `p` + `>`. You can use this rule for every tag you write. Here are a few more examples. Try to see the pattern of opening `<` + tag name + `>` and closing ``. * `Link` * `` * `

    Heading text

    ` # Self-closing tags Not all tags have to correspond to a closing tags. Sometimes it wouldn't make sense to have any text inside the tag. For example, a `

    ` means a paragraph so you would expect some text inside. However, an `` tag means an image and a `

challenges.title: Enter CSS
challenges.testCode: // test('message', () => expect(...))
challenges.supplementaryContent:
CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets, but that's unimportant. What matters here is that what CSS is how you change the way things _look_ on the web. Where HTML is the "stuff", the actual content on a webpage, CSS is how all that stuff looks. Is the background dark with light text (like what you're reading right now)? Is there a menu bar near the top? How does the form on screen try to grab your attention with color and positioning? These are all questions CSS can answer. To be specific, CSS tells the browser two things: * What we want to style * What we want it to look like # Selectors Selectors tell the browser what you want to style. For example, you might say to yourself "I want all the paragraphs on my site to be red!" A very elegant design decision. In order to communicate this to the browser we can use CSS: ```css p { color: red; } ``` Remember the `

` tag from earlier lessons? Using the tagname, `p`, we were able to "select" every paragraph on the page and make them all red. In this example `p` is the selector. Now let's talk about what's inside those brackets. # Properties CSS properties tell the browser how you want something to look. Let's say you're tired of drab white-background websites and want to mix it up with a `teal` background. ```css body { background: teal; } ``` `body` will select the entire visible area of the web page, but we will touch on that more later. Focus on `background: teal;`. Here we have another CSS property `background` with a value of `teal`. > CSS properties take the form: property name + `:` + property value + `;`. `background` and `color` are just two examples. There are quite a few CSS properties you can use, and the combination of them is responsible for styling every site you use on the internet. If you're curious you can skim through [the full list of CSS properties](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Properties_Reference), but we don't recommend it. It's a very dry read and by itself won't tell you what you really want to know which is what each property does. Furthermore, some CSS properties are so obscure that you can go your entire career without learning them on the job because they are just not useful in most context. # Blocks A "block" of CSS is simply the combination of selectors and properties. All the examples above are CSS blocks. > CSS blocks take the form: Selectors + `{` + properties + `}` These terms are not important for their own sake, but so that you aren't lost when you're working outside of this course. # The `

Red text!

``` If you write that without the `style` tag the browser will literally put `p { color: red; }` on the page for everyone to see. By putting that CSS code within a `style` tag you are telling the browser to treat it as CSS rather than HTML. # Specificity and the HTML `class` and `id` props Imagine you have two paragraphs, and you want one to be `red` and the other to be `blue`. How would you select just one? Here's the HTML: ```html

I want a blue background

I want a red background

``` You might try the following CSS: ``` p { background: red; } p { background: blue; } ``` However, both paragraphs will be `blue`! Why? Two things are happening here: 1. `p` selects every `

` tag, not just the first or the second. 2. When you have two identical selectors (`p` and `p` above) and two identical property names (`background` and `background` above) whichever one comes last wins. Point 1 can be addressed with IDs and classes, which we will discuss shortly. Point 2, how conflicting styles get applied by the browser, is called "specificity". As in, the second CSS block is considered more _specific_ than the first, and therefore it wins and gets applied. ## IDs An ID is a unique identifier in the browser and it can be used as a selector. * There should only be 1 of any ID on a web page. * IDs are very specific, meaning if you select an ID in your CSS that CSS will most likely win over other styles * HTML uses the `id` property, CSS uses the `#` selector. ```html

Red text!

``` Even though the `p` styles come last, the `#my-paragraph` styles get applied because they are more specific. > In general don't use IDs, use classes. ## Classes * A class can be applied to as many things as you want. * Classes are more specific than tag names * HTML uses the `class` property, CSS uses the `.` selector. ```html

Red text!

``` The text is again red because classes are more specific than tag names. > Classes are extremely useful and flexible. Use them a lot. # More to come... That's a lot of information, and mostly meaningless without practice. There's more to CSS which we will dive into later, but for now let's practice everything we just talked about.

challenges.supplementaryContent:
# The `<body>` tag

I this lesson we touched on the `<body>` tag, which the browser will insert into the document for you if you don't do it yourself.

# HTML colors

In HTML there are several ways to define colors. The most simple is what we've been doing so far, which is using colors that have names like `blue`, `red`, `black`, `green`, etc. However, if you had to rely on colors that have names you would be quite limited. HTML let's you define any custom color you want using some different syntax, namely HEX codes. For example, the color `white` can also be written `#ffffff`. Likewise `black` is `#000000` and `blue` is `#0000ff`. 

In the meantime you can use named colors. There are quite a few, and often if you guess a color it will exist. You can see the full list here: <https://www.w3schools.com/colors/colors_names.asp>

challenges.title: Highliting text
challenges.content:
Use the `<span>` tag to highligh some text within the paragraph.

Sometimes you want to style parts of text _inside_ a paragraph or a heading. You can accomplish this with the span tag.

* Create a `highlight-blue` class and apply it to one of the span tags
* Style the `highlight` so that it has a `yellow` background

This lesson is all about CSS class names and how they can be used to style different things. Check out the supplemental content area below for more.

challenges.supplementaryContent:
# To style many things

CSS classes give you a ton of flexibility when styling your HTML. You can utilize classes to style one type of tag in many different ways. You can also utilize CSS classes to overwrite default styles since they have greater specificity.

The CSS lesson includes more information.

challenges.supplementaryContent:
# Padding

Padding means "space inside" of something. This is why we had you change some background colors in this challenge. Without a background color it's hard to tell where the padding is. Of course you don't always want to show how wide or slim something is, so it's up to you whether or not you use padding with a background or without.

Padding without a background color can be used just like margin to separate things, however, visual space created by padding is only visual space. The element with padding itself becomes wider. This can be very useful for things like menus and buttons, where you want something to have a large clickable area even if the element itself isn't very large on screen.

# Display Properties

The `display` property is very important in CSS. It determines how HTML elements interact with each other on the page. For example, `<a>` tags have a default display property of `inline`, which means other components can ignore their vertical padding. However, `inline-block` means their padding cannot be ignored, and you will get the results you see in this challenge.

Some important display properties:

* `display: block;` This is the default for most elements (`div`, `p`, `h1`, etc) and puts things on their own line.
* `display: inline-block;` This is useful when you want things to line up horizontally (`a` tags in a horizontal menu for example) and you also want to add margins or padding.
* `display: flex;` This is useful when you want child elements to expand or contract to fit available space. This display property is super flexible, and you might find yourself using it all the time once you know it.

These display properties will make up most of your UI. The web app you're using right now was built with only these display properties.

challenges.title: Columns and Rows -- The display property
challenges.content:
* Make the `.horizontal-nav` links have a bottom margin of `20px`.
* Make the `.vertical-nav` links stack one on top of another using the `display` property. I.e. make it into a vertical nav.

By default `<a>` tags have `display: inline`, however you can change this.
* If you need a **row**, try `display: inline-block`.
* If you need a **column**, try `display: block`.
challenges.starterCode:
A horizontal nav

Home About Contact

A vertical-nav nav

Home About Contact
challenges.solutionCode:
A horizontal nav

Home About Contact

A vertical-nav nav

Home About Contact
challenges.supplementaryContent:
Every HTML element has a default `display` property. This can be confusing since it's easy to forget what the default is for a given tag. But there's a trick: 

**Don't worry about what the default is**. 

Rather than try to remember what the default display property for an element is just look at it and adjust accordingly. If you want something to line up in a row you can set `display: inline-block` and if you want things to stack on top of each other use `display: block`.

There are other display values besides `block` and `inline-block` but you won't use most of them very often. There is however one more very important display property called `flex`, which we will cover in another challenge.

challenges.title: Flexbox -- Creating an evenly-spaced nav menu
challenges.content: * Use the `display` property and `justify-content` property to evenly space the links in `.mobile-nav`
challenges.starterCode: Home About Contact
challenges.solutionCode: Home About Contact
challenges.supplementaryContent:
Ever notice how mobile nav menus on a phone are often spaced perfectly so that the icons fill the space on screen? 

This effect is quite simple to accomplish with CSS and Flexbox. 

Flexbox is the general term for CSS that utilizes the `display: flex` property. Display `flex` lets you do a lot of things that used to be very difficult in web browsers. Things like:

* Create equal spacing between elements (this challenge!)
* Create equal space around elements
* Vertically or horizontally center elements

There are other uses for Flexbox but these are some of the most common.
